repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This is a subset of PR #2951, containing the code concerning nested class definition support.

For the records, you'll find below the original #2951 description of theses changes:

-------------------

## 4 - Nested classes
This is not about wrapping nested C++ classes, because it is already present and functional (and there's a test which can prove it).
This is about being able to generate C++ classes definitions with nested classes. So it is exactly like the batch about method overloading: being able to define and not just declare.
If I have understood it properly, this addresses issue #1218

a) Make cppclass generate code for nested definitions (for example nested cppclass)
b) Fix Symtab for the inherited nested types: this is basically the same thing than for other attributes, have a separate "inherited types" array, to be able to have them in scope but ignore them during code generation.
c) Amend the nested classes test

comment_data.body: Adding `_WARNINGS` doesn't do much by itself. If you also add `tag: warnings` then it checks that the warnings match what you given. If you're just aiming to ignore the warnings then it isn't needed.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -249,3 +249,7 @@ def test_uncopyable_constructor_argument():
     cdef UncopyableConstructorArgument *c = new UncopyableConstructorArgument(
         unique_ptr[vector[int]](new vector[int]()))
     del c
+
+_WARNINGS="""

comment_data.body:
I think I wanted to be double safe by both removing the `werror` tag and adding `_WARNINGS`. Pragmatically, that warning comes from a test I didn't write, so I don't really know if matching that warning is important or not.
I can dive a bit into the code to see if that could be relevant to try to match that warning. If it's not relevant, I guess just removing the `werror` tag would be the right move.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -249,3 +249,7 @@ def test_uncopyable_constructor_argument():
     cdef UncopyableConstructorArgument *c = new UncopyableConstructorArgument(
         unique_ptr[vector[int]](new vector[int]()))
     del c
+
+_WARNINGS="""

comment_data.body:
Here we are in the C++ code generation part.

The base behaviour is to put all the numeric type definitions early in the generated C++ code (the `numeric_typedefs` section), regardless of where they are defined in the cython code.

When we are generating nested numeric type definitions, i.e. we are defining a numeric type inside a cppclass, we don't want that numeric type to be defined elsewhere than inside the cppclass namespace. So, when we are in a cppclass, we avoid escaping numeric types to the `numeric_typedefs` section.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -972,7 +972,8 @@ def generate_gcc33_hack(self, env, code):
 
     def generate_typedef(self, entry, code):
         base_type = entry.type.typedef_base_type
-        if base_type.is_numeric:
+        enclosing_scope = entry.scope
+        if base_type.is_numeric and not enclosing_scope.is_cpp_class_scope:

comment_data.body:
Here we are in the C++ code generation part.

Just added the correct method to generate the C++ code for the types defined inside a given cppclass in the cython code.

C++ code generation wise, this is in fact the main intent of this PR, the rest is more bug fix than feature addition.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1048,6 +1049,7 @@ def generate_cpp_class_definition(self, entry, code):
                     [base_class.empty_declaration_code() for base_class in type.base_classes])
                 code.put(" : public %s" % base_class_decl)
             code.putln(" {")
+            self.generate_type_header_code(scope.type_entries, code)

comment_data.body:
Here we are in the AST (type) analysis part.

In a cppclass, the same way we are bubbling up functions nested inside a CompilerDirectivesNode, we are bubbling up defined methods of nested cppclass.

After two years without looking at Cython code, my understanding of this part of the PR is fragile.

From what I'm able to recall ( / bet) this is for adding nested methods definitions like `ClassA.ClassB.method1()`
into the C++ code generation pipeline. I guess without that, the nested methods are just declared, and their code is not generated in the C++ code.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1582,6 +1582,9 @@ def func_attributes(attributes):
                 elif isinstance(attr, CompilerDirectivesNode):
                     for sub_attr in func_attributes(attr.body.stats):
                         yield sub_attr
+                elif isinstance(attr, CppClassNode) and attr.attributes is not None:
+                    for sub_attr in func_attributes(attr.attributes):
+                        yield sub_attr

comment_data.body:
Here we are in the AST type declaration part.

The goal here is to make inherited types accessible for derived classes. Let's take an example.
I define a parent cppclass `ClassA`, and inside `ClassA`, I define a type `MyNestedType`. This is a type nested inside `ClassA`.
Now, I make a class `ClassB` which inherits from `ClassA`.

The goal of the patch in Symtab is to be able to write in cython code something like `cdef ClassB.MyNestedType my_var`.

The `defining=0` part is for avoiding redefining again `MyNestedType` in the C++ code defining `ClassB`.

I'm not at all a fluent reader of the C++ norms, so I don't know if that "nested type transitivity" is an actual feature of C++, I just saw that implementation-wise, g++ allows that, so I made that happen into the Cython compiler.

It looks like the example I just gave has no unit test. I'm gonna make one, hopefully soon.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2705,12 +2706,13 @@ def declare_inherited_cpp_attributes(self, base_class):
                                            modifiers=base_entry.func_modifiers,
                                            utility_code=base_entry.utility_code)
             entry.is_inherited = 1
-        for base_entry in base_scope.type_entries:
+        for base_entry in base_scope.type_entries + base_scope.inherited_type_entries:
             if base_entry.name not in base_templates:
                 entry = self.declare_type(base_entry.name, base_entry.type,
                                           base_entry.pos, base_entry.cname,
-                                          base_entry.visibility)
+                                          base_entry.visibility, defining=0)
                 entry.is_inherited = 1
+                self.inherited_type_entries.append(entry)

comment_data.body:
The behaviour sounds reasonable - it's consistent with what both Python and C++ does (although C++ behaviour depends a bit on the visibility).

On a quick read I'm not convinced we need the `self.inherited_type_entries`. Since you redeclare them, don't they end up in `type_entries`? (Or am I wrong here?)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2705,12 +2706,13 @@ def declare_inherited_cpp_attributes(self, base_class):
                                            modifiers=base_entry.func_modifiers,
                                            utility_code=base_entry.utility_code)
             entry.is_inherited = 1
-        for base_entry in base_scope.type_entries:
+        for base_entry in base_scope.type_entries + base_scope.inherited_type_entries:
             if base_entry.name not in base_templates:
                 entry = self.declare_type(base_entry.name, base_entry.type,
                                           base_entry.pos, base_entry.cname,
-                                          base_entry.visibility)
+                                          base_entry.visibility, defining=0)
                 entry.is_inherited = 1
+                self.inherited_type_entries.append(entry)

comment_data.body: I think it depends on what the warning is...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -249,3 +249,7 @@ def test_uncopyable_constructor_argument():
     cdef UncopyableConstructorArgument *c = new UncopyableConstructorArgument(
         unique_ptr[vector[int]](new vector[int]()))
     del c
+
+_WARNINGS="""

comment_data.body: Probably `defining=False` instead of `0` (a lot of Cython code predates the bool I believe, so is written with 0, but there's no need to keep it like that with new code)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2705,12 +2706,13 @@ def declare_inherited_cpp_attributes(self, base_class):
                                            modifiers=base_entry.func_modifiers,
                                            utility_code=base_entry.utility_code)
             entry.is_inherited = 1
-        for base_entry in base_scope.type_entries:
+        for base_entry in base_scope.type_entries + base_scope.inherited_type_entries:
             if base_entry.name not in base_templates:
                 entry = self.declare_type(base_entry.name, base_entry.type,
                                           base_entry.pos, base_entry.cname,
-                                          base_entry.visibility)
+                                          base_entry.visibility, defining=0)

comment_data.body:
Oh you're right, I was quite blindly mimicking what is done for variables, where we use `declare()` for inherited variables and not `declare_var`. `self.inherited_type_entries` is indeed useless, that's on my todo-list for the next update of this PR, along with a test for nested type transitivity.
Thanks for catching that mistake !
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2705,12 +2706,13 @@ def declare_inherited_cpp_attributes(self, base_class):
                                            modifiers=base_entry.func_modifiers,
                                            utility_code=base_entry.utility_code)
             entry.is_inherited = 1
-        for base_entry in base_scope.type_entries:
+        for base_entry in base_scope.type_entries + base_scope.inherited_type_entries:
             if base_entry.name not in base_templates:
                 entry = self.declare_type(base_entry.name, base_entry.type,
                                           base_entry.pos, base_entry.cname,
-                                          base_entry.visibility)
+                                          base_entry.visibility, defining=0)
                 entry.is_inherited = 1
+                self.inherited_type_entries.append(entry)

comment_data.body: Understood, that'll end up in the next update of this PR.

                                            modifiers=base_entry.func_modifiers,

-                                          base_entry.visibility)

commit.message: Fix Symtab for CppClassScope nested types
Amend cpp nested test case for cython-defined cppclass
Fix test case cpp_classes_def: add expected warning
